<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
No conflicts as of last run.
Please keep to the convention of starting thread names with `b-`.

> Please keep to the convention of starting thread names with `b-`.

It is responsibility of the `ThreadRename()` function: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/36c0abd8f61ba859d53b1e59014720282c97c143/src/util/threadnames.cpp#L57-L61

:)

UPDATE: On the screenshot in OP you can see all of the touched threads with `b-` prefix in the `htop` output.
> It is responsibility of the ThreadRename() function: \n\nThanks for clearing that up.

Updated da42cd4ac1e1574a45578b04aab6e2a39653fc0e -> 64815f1f0da3431f2c2f880aeef4d57c3acd8aa5 ([pr18790.01](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr18790.01) -> [pr18790.02](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr18790.02), [diff](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/compare/pr18790.01..pr18790.02)):\n\n- dropped _"Name leveldb thread with its own name"_ commit

ACK 64815f1f0da3431f2c2f880aeef4d57c3acd8aa5

./src/qt/bitcoin-qt -logthreadnames -debug -printtoconsole -regtest                      (7s 63ms)  
2020-05-01T09:48:48Z Ignoring unknown configuration value regtest.na
@brakmic \nThank you for reviewing. Mind particularly testing the changed threads: `qt-clientmodl`, `qt-rpcconsole`, and `qt-walletctrl`?

> @brakmic
> Thank you for reviewing. Mind particularly testing the changed threads: `qt-clientmodl`, `qt-rpcconsole`, and `qt-walletctrl`?

Yes, sure. 

I was able to get `qt-rpcconsole` and `qt-walletctrl` but no matter what I do and whichever window I open, there is no `qt-clientmodl` in sight. 

![qt-rpcconsole](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/brakmic/bazaar/master/images/rando

> @brakmic
> 
> > ... but no matter what I do and whichever window I open, there is no `qt-clientmodl` in sight.
> 
> It's because there is no logging in the `qt-clientmodl` thread. But `b-qt-clientmodl` should be showed by the OS via tools similar to `ps`, `top` etc.

Ok. 

I took a sample from the running process and here's the `b-qt-clientmodl`thread.

Rebased f979110c851372b8702c3ae99e21f2e578640e4b -> ead771bf6fc7a4b96a03d4938796c88657c69ba6 ([pr18790.04](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr18790.04) -> [pr18790.05](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr18790.05)) due to the conflict with #19011.
Planning on reviewing (shortly) and merging this PR in this repo. @promag @jb55 @jonatack @Sjors want to take another look here?
tACK ead771bf6fc7a4b96a03d4938796c88657c69ba6
Why is this needed? Also, calling this leveldb is a layer-violation.
leveldb spawns a thread which inherits current thread name: "bitcoind" or "qt-init". Therefore, on master the OS reports about two "bitcoind" threads.
Oh, I see. Maybe add a comment?
Mind suggesting a good wording?

To be honest, I think it's better to leave this out than do an ugly layer violation like this.
At the least this would need to be documented very well, just having a scattered thread rename is confusing for anyone reading the code in the future.
But I wonder if there's a better way to hook leveldb's thread creation and rename the threads.
Is it ok to just drop a commit with this change for better solution?
It seemed weird anyway to to gui changes in the same pull request with leveldb changes
[Updated](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18790#issuecomment-622099051).
